result.name: repeats
result.help_text: The repetition interval determines how long it will take to rotate each member in the schedule. For example , if the option "Daily" is selected , then each member's shift in your schedule will rotate on a daily basis. Additionally if "Weekly" is selected then each shift will continue for a week before rotating to the next member in your roster. Members will be defined in the next section of the wizard. You will be able to refine your choices after creating the schedule

result.name: name
result.help_text: An arbitrary name that will be displayed in lists and in record detail.  If you will have mulitple LDAP servers then pick names that help you to identify the server being used.

result.name: server_url
result.help_text:
This is the combination of the server name and server port where your LDAP Server is listening.  Frequently the port is either 389 which is the default port for connectng to LDAP in clear text or 636 which is the standard port for connecting to LDAP via an SSL connection.  You can specify more than one URL address for your LDAP Server.  This does NOT establish multiple directory structures from which you can import data (which is done by creating another LDAP Server entry) but does provide for redundancy when you have multiple LDAP Servers to avoid a single point of failure.  Separate the LDAP URL address with a space character and the system will automatically try each server address in turn until a valid connection can be made.

Example value:  ldap://10.10.10.3:389/

result.name: rdn
result.help_text:
The Starting search directory or RDN (Relative Distinguished Name) where you want Service-now to begin its search for users and/or groups.  No data ABOVE this point will be available for import.  Service-now will only have visibility into the directory from this point specified and below in the LDAP hierarchy.

Example value: DC=service-now,DC=com

result.name: backup_source
result.help_text: Specify the database from which you wish to restore. The default is to restore a database from its own backups, but you can specify a different database to be your restore source as well. This allows you to replace one database with a recent backup of another, which is often useful for setting up test systems.

result.sys_name: Restore from this point in time
result.name: restore_pit
result.help_text: Indicate which point in time you wish to restore from. Default (if you leave this blank) is to restore from the most recent available backup. However, it is possible to restore from an earlier point in time if necessary.
result.question_text: Restore from this point in time

result.tooltip: Select request type to create or modify
result.name: request_type
cpu_speed
result.help_text: The CPU, or Central Processing Unit, is the "engine" of your computer. Computers with faster CPUs will generally run faster than those with slower CPUs, although, as with an automobile engine there are downsides to high CPU speed, notably cost, heat generation, and power consumption. For our organization, we are recommending the default (2.66GHz) processor for all machines with the exception of the graphics department (recommended 3.73GHz) and the develepment staff (recommended 3.00 GHz).
